nodes.label: Carderera

nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara; member of the Junta del Museo Nacional y del Museo Real de Pintura y Escultura (currently the Prado Museum), from 1838; teacher of Theory and History of Fine Arts at the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando; vice-director of the Real Museo de Pintura y Escultura (current Prado Museum)

nodes.writes in: El Artista, Semanario Pintoresco español, El Museo Universal, La Gazette des Beaux-arts

nodes.decorations/awards: Gran Cruz de Carlos III (1844)
nodes.author of: Iconografía espan̂ola: Colección de retratos, estatuas, mausoleos y demás monumentos (...), in Spanish and French, 1855-1864
mentions of Goya: 1835 El Artista 2, 'Biografía de D. Francisco Goya, pintor', 253-55: 'La nueva escuela romántica de los pintores franceses ha puesto en evidencia el mérito de nuestro artista, y en bastantes cuadros pequeños y en muchísimas litografías y aguas fuertes que adornan las ediciones de Victor Hugo y otros célebres contemporáneos, se ve el deseo de imitar a Goya, y se columbran los originales y románticos duendecitos esparcidos en sus ochenta caprichos' (p.255) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.325). With a lithography by Federico Madrazo (Vicente López's portrait of Goya).

1838-VII-15 Semanario Pintoresco español 120, 631-33: 'Los aficionados estrangeros tiempo ha las buscan [Caprichos] con mas pasion que los nuestros, y hoy vemos reproducidos y transformados sus duendecitos y alguaciles en los grabados y litografiados que nos vienen de allende sin pretensión de ocultar el plagio' (p.633) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.328)

1860-VIII-15 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 7, 'François Goya: sa vie, ses dessins et ses eaux-fortes', 215-27, translated and annotated by Philippe Burty, with a preface by Charles Blanc and a print by Bracquemond. It includes a short biography of Goya and an account of his drawings. Carderera claims ownership of 2 sheets from Album A, 112 preparatory drawings of the Caprichos, 50 of Tauromaquia and 72 of Disasters of War (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.347). [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k2030710/f231.item#)

1863-VII-1 Gazette des Beaux-Arts 15, 'François Goya', 237-49. It focuses on the advertisement of the Caprichos in the Diario de Madrid (6 Feb 1799). It includes Jacquemart's 'Spanish scene', based on Goya. Also mentions the Prado commentaries. It quotes Théophile Gautier's essay on the Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, 1845, p.136). He mixes up the Disparates with the drawing series Sueños ('Les proverbes ou rêves', p.244) (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.350). [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k2030791/f257.item#)
nodes.collection of Goya's works: Carderera gathered a large part of Goya's prints and drawings, acquired from Javier and Mariano Goya, and Ceán Bermúdez. He possessed at one time some 400 of Goya's drawings, 272 of which were acquired by the Prado in 1886, as well as the engraved work. His collection also included rare working proofs from the collection of Ceán Bermúdez, now at the BNE (acquired from Carderera in 1867 and from his descendants), as well as the famous proofs from the Stirling-Maxwell collection, now at the Boston Museum (Harris 1964, vol.I, p.11)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2020; Lanzarote Guiral 2016; Harris 1964

nodes.label: Baron Taylor
nodes.profession: politician, artist, playwright, philanthropist, military member
in Spain: July 1833 (with Dauzats): introduced to José Madrazo by Blanchard, portrayed by Madrazo

1835-36 commissioned by Louis-Philippe to acquire paintings for Galerie espagnole (assisted by Dauzats and Blanchard, and benefited by active help and advice from the Madrazo family and Carderera [Lanzarote Guiral 2016 p.574]): 1836 Feb-Aug (8 paintings attributed to Goya from Javier Goya)
nodes.worked for: Charles X; Louis-Philippe: acquiring Spanish paintings for the Galerie espagnole (1838-48)
works as: Administrateur général de la Comédie-Française (1825-30, 1831-38): he stages Alexandre Dumas's 'Henri III et sa cour', and Hugo's 'Hernani' and 'Marion Delorme'.

Commissaire du roi (Charles X) auprès du Pacha d'Égypte (1830): commissioned with gathering Egyptian antiquities for the Louvre (with a credit of 100.000 fr.). He brings the Luxor obelisk to Paris (Place de la Concorde since 1836).
Inspecteur général des Beaux-Arts (1835): Galerie espagnole.
nodes.author of: Voyage pittoresque en Espagne, en Portugal et sur la côte d’Afrique, de Tanger a Tétuan (1826); Voyages pittoresques et romantiques dans l'ancienne France, in collaboration with Charles Nodier and Alphonse de Cailleux (started in 1818; published 1820-1878)
nodes.member of: Académie Française, Académie des beaux-arts (1847); Société des gens de lettres; Fondation Taylor
nodes.portrayed by: Federico Madrazo, oil painting (1833); Nadar, photograph (1877)
nodes.participates in: l'Expédition d'Espagne (1823), also known as los Cien Mil Hijos de San Luis: campaign to restore the Bourbon dinasty in Spain
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier (1822), Officier (1834), Commandeur (1837) et Grand officer (1877) de la Légion d'Honneur
nodes.parents: Hélie Taylor (English born) and Marie-Jacqueline Walwein (Belgian)
nodes.curiosities: There is a Fondation Taylor, still running, created in 1844
nodes.bibliography: Lanzarote Guiral 2016; Guinard 1967-A

nodes.label: Dauzats
nodes.in Spain: in 1832 (with Baron Taylor); July 1833 (with Baron Taylor); 1835-1837 assists Baron Taylor in acquisition of artworks for Galerie espagnole (alongside Pharamond Blanchard)
nodes.author of: 1834 article in Le Magasin pittoresque? (mentions Prado commentaries, in the possession of Javier Goya until 1861) (Guinard 1967-B, p.323)
nodes.bibliography: Guinard 1967-B

nodes.label: Blanchard
in Spain: 1824-1837 working as a painter and engraver; hired by José Madrazo to make lithographic reproductions at the Real Museo in Madrid
1835-37 he assists Baron Taylor and Dauzats in acquiring paintings for Louis Philippe's Galerie espagnole

nodes.label: Eugenio Ochoa
nodes.in Paris: 1828-1834 at the École d'Arts et d'Offices. He meets Moratín and Godoy; 1837-1845
author of: Translation of Victor Hugo's Hernani (watched by Théophile Gautier in 1840 in Valladolid)

1844 Catálogo razonado de los manuscritos españoles existentes en la Biblioteca Real de París: seguido de un suplemento que contiene los de las otras tres bibliotecas públicas (Arsenal, Ste Geneviève and Mazarine), París, Imprenta Real

1861 Paris, Londres y Madrid: he mentions Dumas, Balzac, Gautier, Delacroix, Dauzats, Nodier, Lamartine, Ingres, Vernet, Decamps, Delaroche, Eugène Sue, Feuillet, Houssaye and others. He does not mention Goya, Taylor, Javier Goya or Mariano Goya. HathiTrust [https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=hvd.32044014808356&seq=203&q1=Sand]
nodes.editor of: El Artista (1835) con Federico Madrazo: spreads Romanticism in Spain and imitates the French journal L'Artiste

nodes.label: Mérimée
nodes.profession: writer, historian, archaeologist, anthropologist, playwright, politician, translator, draughtsman
nodes.works as: Inspecteur général des monuments historiques (1834). Senator (1853). He was one of the main translators of Russian into French, and also knew Arabic, English and Greek.
nodes.studied in: Lycée Henri-IV. Then he studies Law and Music (piano), obtaining his final certificate in Rome.
author of: Fiction: La Vénus d'Ille; Carmen (1845 written; 1847 published); Homme en Grande Bottes; Mateo Falcone (1829).

Art criticism and travel literature: Les Grands Maîtres au Musée de Madrid (1830); Lettres d’Espagne (1832): Les Combats de taureaux, Une exécution, Les Voleurs, Les Sorcières espagnoles; Notes de voyages (1835—1840).
nodes.member of: Académie des inscriptions et belles-lettres (1843-1870); Académie française (1844-1870), replacing Charles Nodier; Société des antiquaires de la Morinie; Société de l’histoire de France; Académie du dessin de Florence
nodes.decorations/awards: Grand officier de la Légion d'honneur‎; Grand prix des Meilleurs romans du XIXe siècle (1952)
nodes.visits the Prado Museum: in 1830 (doesn't mention Goya in his account)
nodes.parents: Léonor Mérimée and Anne Louise Moreau
nodes.portrayed by: Anne Moreau in 1808 (as a child); Charles Reutilinger, photograph (1850); Simon Jacques Rochard, pastel, 1852 (Musée Carnavalet); Mathilde Bonaparte, drawing, 1869 (Musée Carnavalet)
nodes.pseudonyms: L' Auteur du Théâtre de Clara Gazul, Clara Gazul, Joseph Lestrange, Hyacinthe Maglanovich
nodes.curiosities: as Inspecteur général des monuments historiques, he named Viollet-le-Duc in charge of the restoration of the Vézelay basilica (1840), the cathedral Notre-Dame de Paris (1843) and the Cité de Carcassonne (1853). He was a close friend of Empress Eugènie (Eugenia de Montijo). In 1978 a 'base Mérimée' was created in his honour for the classification of historical monuments in France.

nodes.label: Montijo
nodes.full name: María Eugenia Ignacia Agustina de Palafox y Kirkpatrick
nodes.aristocratic titles: XI Countess of Mora and Grandee of Spain, XVII Baroness of Quinto, XVIII Marchioness of Moya, XIX Countess of Teba, XVI Marchioness of Ardales, IX Marchioness of Osera, IX Countess of Ablitas, XII Countess of Baños, IX Countess of Santa Cruz de la Sierra
nodes.political views: she embraced the Bonapartist cause; she advocated equality for women: she tried (unsuccessfully) to convince the Académie Française to elect George Sand as its first female member; she personally intervened on behalf of Julie-Victoire Daubié for the signing of her baccalaureate diploma; she also intervened for the award of the Légion d'honneur to painter Rosa Bonheur; and obtained Madeleine Brès's enrolment in the Faculty of Medicine
nodes.siblings: María Francisca de Sales (Paca), who marries the XV Duke of Alba in 1849

nodes.parents: Cipriano de Palafox y Portocarrero and María Manuela Kirkpatrick de Grevignée

nodes.label: Bonheur

nodes.parents: Oscar-Raymond Bonheur and Sophie Marquis
nodes.decorations/awards: chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1865); officière de la Légion d'honneur (1894)
nodes.portrayed by: David d'Angers, 1856, medallion; Edouard Louis Dubufe, 1857, oil painting, Palace de Versailles; Charles-Michel Geoffroy, 1859, print; Eugène Disdéri, 1865, photograph; Anna Klumpke, 1898, oil painting, Metropolitan; c.1900, photograph, Musée Rosa Bonheur
nodes.curiosities: Rosa's father, Raymond Bonheur, was a painter who met and befriended Goya and Moratín in Bordeaux

nodes.label: Marcello
nodes.full name: Adélaïde Nathalie Marie Hedwige Philippine d’Affry
nodes.in Spain: in 1868 (during the Revolution): she meets painters Henri Regnault and Georges Clarin; she meets and makes a bust after Milans del Bosch; with recommentation letters from Mérimée, Marcello has access to the Prado Museum, and admires, among others, the work of Velázquez (probably of Goya too).
author of: Sculpture: La Belle Hélène (1860); La Gorgone (Salon 1865); L'Imperatrice Eugénie (1866); Marie-Antoinette à Versailles (1866); Hécate (Exposition universelle 1867, commissioned by Napoléon III); La Bacchante fatiguée (1869); La Mauresque souriante (1869); La Pythie (1870); Portrait de madame de Tallenay (1873); La Baronne Keffenbrinck (Salon 1876).
Painting: La Conjuration de Fiesque (Salon 1874: rejected); Portrait de Berthe Morisot (1875).

Printmaking (since 1860): dark, grotesque etchings clearly inspired by Goya's prints, mainly the Disasters of War (see Fayos Pérez 2024, fig.II.68, Marcello, Vision of human skulls); she made 9 etchings and some lithographs inspired by Eugène Delacroix (1873).
Writing: Mémoires, unfinished
nodes.masters: Sculpture: Heinrich Max Imhof, Antoine-Louis Barye (Muséum national d'histoire naturally), Auguste Clésinger. Painting: Ernest Hébert (drawing, at the Villa Médicis), Mariano Fortuny (at his workshop, she meets Eduardo Rosales), Léon Bonnat (from 1872); Marcellin Desboutin (printmaking).
nodes.parents: Louis d'Affry and Lucie d'Affry de Maillardo
nodes.address: 1, rue Bayard, from 1859 (rented to Léon Riesener, Eugène Delacroix's cousin)
nodes.portrayed by: Adolphe Dallemagne, c.1866-67, photograph (BNF); Gustave Courbet, 1870 (Musée de Reims); Edouard-Théophile Blanchard, oil painting, 1877 (Musée d'art et d'histoire de Fribourg)
nodes.decorations/awards: medal for her works at the Exposition universelle de 1873 (Vienna): Le Chef abyssin, Bianca Capello, 2 Marie-Antoinette, Pythie
nodes.curiosities: she refused to be portrayed by Édouard Manet. She was also a great admirer of music, and met Charles Gounod and Franz Liszt. In her will, she donates her work to the city of Fribourg, under the condition of creating a museum.
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; François Géal, 2017, 'Mérimée/Goya, chronique d'un désamour annoncé', Cahiers Mérimée, pp.55; Gianna A. Mina (dir.), Marcello, Adèle d'Affry (1836-1879), duchesse de Castiglione Colonna, catalogue d'exposition, Fribourg, Musée d'art et d'histoire, 2014; 1980 exhibition catalogue, Fribourg (Dictionnaire de l'estampe 1830-1950, 1985, p.213); Odette d'Alcantara, Marcello : Adèle d'Affry, duchesse Castiglione-Colonna, 1836–1879, sa vie, son œuvre, sa pensée et ses amis, Genève, Éditions générales, 1961

nodes.label: Iriarte
nodes.works for: Fernando VI, Carlos III, Carlos IV, José I (Joseph Bonaparte)
nodes.member of: Real Academia Española; Real Academia de Ciencias y Artes de Barcelona
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1797, Strasbourg Museum of Fine Arts

nodes.label: Ferdinand Guillemardet
nodes.profession: diplomat (French ambassador 1798-1800), medical doctor, politician (representative of the Convention)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1798, Louvre
nodes.collector of Goya's works: a set of the Caprichos; his portrait (1798, Louvre MI697); Portrait of Mariana Waldstein, 9th Marquise of Santa Cruz (c.1797-99, Louvre RF1976-79) [authorship doubts]
nodes.commissions Goya with: portrait, 1798, Louvre MI697 (GW.677). This was the first work by Goya to enter the Louvre (donated by his heirs in 1865)

nodes.label: Delacroix
nodes.author of: La Barque de Dante (1822, Louvre); Scenes from the Massacre at Chios (1824, Louvre); Nature morte aux Homards (1826-27, Louvre); The Death of Sardanapalus (1827, Louvre); Liberty guiding the People (1830, Louvre); Les Femmes d'Alger (1834, Louvre); Médée (1838, Lille); Hamlet et Horatio au cimetière (1839); décor de la bibliothèque de l'Assemblée national (Palais Bourbon) (1838-1847); décor de la bilbiothèque du Sénat (palais Luxembourg) (1840-1846); décor de la Galerie d'Apollon (Louvre) (1850-1851); Le Christ sur le lac de Génésareth (1854); décor de Saint-Sulpice (1850-1861)
nodes.studies in: École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts; Lycée Louis-le-Grand; Lycée Pierre-Corneille de Rouen
nodes.member of: Société héliographique (from 1851): the first of its kind to be focused on photography
nodes.in Spain: in 1832: 'Tout Goya palpitait autour de moi'
nodes.knows Goya's works: by c.1819, through Ferdinand Guillemardet (Lipschutz 1972, p.10)
nodes.students: Pierre Andrieu, Gustave de Lassalle-Borde, Louis de Planet, Maurice Sand. In 1841 he opens a workshop with students in order to complete different commissions.
nodes.influenced by: Géricault, Antoine-Jean Gros, Pierre Paul Rubens, Francisco de Goya
nodes.parents: Victoire Œben and Charles-François Delacroix
nodes.decorations/awards: Commandeur de la Légion d'honneur‎ (1855)
nodes.portrayed by: Delacroix/Géricault, c.1816, Rouen (oil painting); Nadar, 1858 (photograph)
nodes.curiosities: he became interested in photography since 1851, and commissioned the photographer Eugène Durieu with a series of pictures of nude models (male and female)
nodes.bibliography: Sébastien Allard et al., 2018 exhibition catalogue, Louvre; Maurice Sérullaz, 1989, Delacroix

nodes.label: Llorente
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'afrancesados'
nodes.collector of Goya's works: his portrait (1810-11); a set of the Caprichos (probably bought c.1810 when sitting for his portrait).
nodes.disseminates Goya's works: he brings his Caprichos set to France in 1813 during his exile, and wrote an interpretation of them in French (Boston MFA 1973.730), probably to be shared among French speakers (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.35). Since Goya himself was alive in 1813 and in possession of his original explanations of the Caprichos (known as the Prado commentaries), Llorente probably knew this text directly through him, perhaps during his portrait sittings (c.1810)
nodes.works as: Comisario General de Cruzada (1810-11); Comisario del Santo Oficio; Secretario supernumerario de la Inquisición de Corte; canon of Calahorra (1790); literary censor for the Consejo de Castilla; member of the Junta Nacional for Joseph Bonaparte, Consejero de Estado para Asuntos Eclesiásticos, and Caballero comendador de la Orden Real de España (1809)
nodes.in France: exiled from July 1813, first at Lectoure, then Bordeaux, then Paris (1814). In Paris, he publishes 'Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole' (1817-18) in 4 volumes.
nodes.in Spain: back in 1820, after being expelled from France (during the Bourbon restoration) for being a liberal and a Carbonari
nodes.political views: liberal. Supporter of Regalism. Member of Carbonari (secret revolutionary society, patriotic and liberal in nature). Works for the reform of the clergy in Spain
nodes.studies in: Universidad de Zaragoza. Doctor in Canonical Law
nodes.author of: a report about the Inquisition (1793); Histoire critique de l'Inquisition espagnole (1817-18) in 4 volumes; Retrato político de los Papas (1823); Historia crítica de la inquisición de España (1835).
nodes.member of: Real Sociedad Económica de La Rioja (1805)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1810-11, Museo de Arte de São Paulo
nodes.decorations/awards: Orden Real de España
nodes.curiosities: he wrote a zarzuela, El recluta gallego (1782)

nodes.label: Brugada
nodes.curiosities: he sees Goya die in Bordeaux, alongside Molina (Canellas, Diplomatario,  no.181, p.512)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Ceán Bermúdez
nodes.considered as: part of the group of Spanish 'ilustrados'
nodes.works as: manager of the Archivo de Indias; Secretary's officer for the Estado de Gracia y Justicia de Indias
nodes.member of: RABASF
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Goya gave a vast number of his works to Ceán Bermúdez, including rare working proofs (now at the BNE); this collection was later acquired by Valentín Carderera
nodes.author of: Colección lithographica de cuadros del Rey de España el Sr. D. Fernando VII (1826-37); Diccionario histórico de los más ilustres profesores de las Bellas Artes en España (1800); Sumario de las antigüedades romanas que hay en España, en especial las pertenecientes a las Bellas Artes (1832, postumous)
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1785 (private collection)
nodes.collector of: Dürer, José de Ribera, Piranesi, among others
nodes.married to: Manuela Camas y de las Heras

nodes.label: Esteve
nodes.studies in: Academia de Bellas Artes de San Carlos, Valencia
nodes.masters: Francisco Bayeu; Mariano Salvador Maella; Francisco de Goya
nodes.parents: Agustín Esteve Torralba and María Marqués
nodes.author of: Portrait of the Marchioness of San Andrés de Parma (c.1791); Portrait of Francisco de Borja Téllez-Girón, future X Duke of Osuna (1797, colección Masaveu); Portrait of Martín Antonio Álvarez de Sotomayor y Soto-Flores, conde de Colomera (1798, Prado); Portrait of Manuel Godoy, fundador del Instituto Pestalozzi (c.1806, Museo de Bellas Artes de Valencia); self-portrait, c.1815, Museo Lázaro Galdiano. Copies after Francisco de Goya
nodes.works as: Pintor de Cámara (from 1800); art professor (RABASF)
nodes.member of: RABASF (académico de mérito) (from 1800)
nodes.decorations/awards: first prize of painting at the RABASF (1778)
nodes.bibliography: Albarrán 2018; Albarrán (upcoming)

nodes.label: Moratín
nodes.full name: Leandro Eulogio Melitón Fernández de Moratín y Cabo
nodes.profession: playwright, poet, actor, writer, translator (of Molière and Voltaire)
nodes.works as: Secretary of language interpretation (1797), after the death of one of the Samaniego brothers; member of the Junta de Dirección y Reforma de los Teatros (1799), but he resigns 3 months later; main librarian (bibliotecario mayor) of the Real Biblioteca in 1811, under Joseph Bonaparte (he creates a new catalogue); Juez de Imprentas in 1820 in Barcelona (after the victory of Rafael del Riego)
nodes.founder of: a parodic literary academy called 'Acalófilos o amantes de lo feo' (supporters of the ugly), alongside his friend Juan Tineo Ramírez, nephew of Jovellanos, and the arabist José Antonio Conde; the group was mostly a tertulia (similar to a salon) to read and criticise theatre plays.
nodes.author of: Lección poética. Sátira contra los vicios introducidos en la poesía española (1782); La derrota de los pedantes (1789); La comedia nueva o El café (1792); Apuntaciones sueltas de Inglaterra (1792), Viaje a Italia (1793); translation of Hamlet (1798); El barón (1803); La mojigata (1804); El sí de las niñas (1806), his greatest success; a prologue criticising the recently banished Inquisition, for a failed edition of Fray Gerundio de Campazas (1758) by José Francisco de Isla y Rojo; reedition of Auto de fe celebrado en la ciudad de Logroño en los días 7 y 8 de noviembre del año de 1610 (...) (1811); La escuela de los maridos (1812), with actor Isidoro Máiquez, portrayed by Goya; Obras dramáticas y líricas (1825, Paris). Posthumous: Orígenes del teatro español (1830-1831), Diarios (1968), Epistolario (1973) edited by René Andioc.
in France: In 1787, in a trip accompanying Cabarrús to Paris in a diplomatic mission to advise Louis XVI on counter-revolutionary measures
In his 1792-1797 European tour, he witnessed the assault on the Tuileries on 10 August 1792, and being scared, went to England
1817-1820: fears of the newly restored Inquisition led him back to France on the pretext of taking the waters in Aix-en-Provence; he then went to Montpellier, Paris and Bologna

In 1821 he flees to Bayonne after the plague is declared in Barcelona. He would never return to Spain again. He settles in Bordeaux with his friend Manuel Silvela (also portrayed by Goya). In Bordeaux, he meets Goya again (who makes his second portrait in 1824). He dies in Paris in 1825.
nodes.trips: 1792-1797 European tour (funded by Godoy): France, England, Belgium, Germany, Switzerland, Italy
nodes.member of: Academia de la Arcadia (Roma); Real Academia Española, miembro de número (1821)
nodes.political views: reformist. Supporter of Godoy. Afrancesado
nodes.parents: Isidora Cabo Conde and Nicolás Fernández de Moratín
nodes.decorations/awards: knight of the Orden Real de España in 1811 (under Joseph Bonaparte)
mentions of Goya: Diary, 21 May 1798 (Canellas no.88): they see together the paintings of San Antonio de la Florida?
Moratín writes Silva á D. Francisco Goya, insigne pintor in 1799 to thank him for his newly made portrait [https://es.wikisource.org/wiki/Silva_a_don_Francisco_Goya]
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1799, RABASF; Luis Paret y Alcázar, Museo de Navarra; Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1824, Museo de Bellas Artes de Bilbao
nodes.curiosities: his remains are in the collective mausoleum with Goya, Meléndez Valdés and Donoso Cortés at the Cemetery of San Isidro (Madrid)

nodes.label: Godoy
nodes.full name: Manuel Godoy y Álvarez de Faria Ríos
nodes.aristocratic titles: Príncipe de la Paz, I Marquis and Duke of Alcudia (Grandee of Spain), I Duke of Sueca (Grandee of Spain), I Baron of Mascalbó, VII Prince of Bassano, I Count of Évoramonte, Count of Chinchón (by marriage; Grandee of Spain), and others
nodes.parents: José Alfonso Godoy Cáceres Ovando y Ríos and Antonia Justa Álvarez de Faria y Sánchez Zarzoza
nodes.married to: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga (Condesa de Chinchón); Josefa Tudó y Catalán
nodes.children: Carlota Luisa de Godoy y Borbón; Manuel Luis de Godoy y Tudó; Luis Carlos de Godoy y Tudó
nodes.author of: Memorias de don Manuel Godoy, Príncipe de la Paz, ó sea cuenta dada de su vida política, para servir a la historia del reinado del señor don Carlos IV de Borbón, 6 volumes, 1836-1838. He wrote them in Paris and they were translated into French by Jean-Baptiste Esménard
nodes.mentions of Goya: in his Memorias, Madrid, Imprenta de I. Sancha: t.II, 1836, p.233 (mention of Goya among other artists); t.III, 1836, p.375 ('La calcografia real publicaba la coleccion de vistas del Escorial y las ochenta estampas de los bellos caprichos de don Francisco Goya, dibujados por él mismo'); t.IV, 1837, p.238 (mention of Goya's portrait)
nodes.in France: Carlos IV, María Luisa de Parma and Godoy were first in exile in 1808 in Compiègne, close to Paris
nodes.in Italy: from 1812, Carlos IV, María Luisa de Parma and Godoy were in exile in Rome, first at the Palazzo Borghese, then at the Palazzo Barberini (where María Luisa died in 1819)
nodes.in Paris: after the death of Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma in Italy, Godoy continued his exile in Paris from 1832, where King Louis-Philippe gave him a modest pension, and he focused on the writing of his autobiography. In 1844 and 1847, Queen Isabel II gave him back his titles and properties, but he did not return to Spain. In 1848, he witnessed the revolution in Paris, and the exaltation of Napoleon III
nodes.art collection: his collection included works by Zurbarán, Ribera, Murillo, Rubens, Teniers, Tiziano, Goya and Velázquez (including the famous Venus del espejo, known as the 'Rokeby Venus', now at the London National Gallery). His estates, titles and art collection were expropriated when Godoy went into exile, and there are unanswered questions about, for instance, the dubious ways in which the 'Rokeby Venus' ended up in England
nodes.patronage: he commissioned portraits from all the main artists of the moment, including Goya
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Godoy commissioned Goya with a portrait (1801) and the two celebrated 'Majas': the Maja vestida and the Maja desnuda, both paintings now at the Prado (see Goya-Godoy edge).
nodes.rivals: Count of Floridablanca; Count of Aranda; Ferdinand VII
nodes.bibliography: José Belmonte Díaz & Pilar Leseduarte, Godoy: historia documentada de un expolio, 2004; Memorias de don Manuel Godoy, Príncipe de la Paz, ó sea cuenta dada de su vida política, para servir a la historia del reinado del señor don Carlos IV de Borbón, 6 volumes, 1839-1841
nodes.works as: Guardia de Corps (1784), for Carlos III; Mariscal de campo (Field Marshal) (Feb 1791), teniente general (July 1791), Generalísimo (1801) and Gran almirante (1807) of the Reales Ejércitos; Primer Secretario de Estado (1792-1798) and President of the Consejo de Estado; Almirante general de España e Indias (1807) (Alteza Serenísima); Primer Ministro; Jefe superior de los Reales Cuerpos de Artillería e Ingenieros; Ayudante general del Real Cuerpo de Guardias de Corps; Coronel general de la Guardia Suiza Pontificia; Gentilhombre de la Cámara del Rey con ejercicio; Superintendente general de la Renta de Correos (1792-1798)
decorations/awards: Spain: Caballero de la Orden del Toisón de Oro; Gran Cruz de la Orden de Cristo; Caballero de la Orden de Carlos III; Caballero de la Real y Militar Orden de San Hermenegildo; Caballero (1789) y comendador (1790) de la Orden de Santiago. Also he was named protector of the Real Academia de Nobles Artes y de los Reales Institutos de Historia Natural, Jardín Botánico, Laboratorio Químico and the Observatory

Foreign: Bailío gran cruz de la Orden de San Juan de Jerusalén; Caballero de la Orden de la Legión de Honor; Caballero de la Suprema Orden de Cristo (Reino de Portugal); Caballero de la Suprema Orden de Cristo (Estados Pontificios); Caballero de la Orden de San Jenaro (Reino de las Dos Sicilias); Caballero de la Orden de San Fernando y el Mérito (Reino de las Dos Sicilias)
nodes.political views: extremely loyal to Carlos IV and María Luisa de Parma, who gave him countless decorations and aristocratic titles. He limited the power of the high aristocracy. In 1797, he formed a government considered ilustrado: Jovellanos (Secretary of Justice), Francisco de Saavedra (Hacienda), Cabarrús (creator of Banco de San Carlos): sent to Paris as ambassador; he also included Meléndez Valdés and Mariano Luis de Urquijo. Most of these politicians were portrayed by Goya, and many were also his friends.
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Folch de Cardona, 1788, RABASF; Francisco Bayeu, 1792, RABASF; Juan Adán, 1794, RABASF (sculpture: bust); Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1794, private collection (equestrian portrait); Agustín Esteve, 1800, Chicago Art Institute; Francisco de Goya y Lucientes, 1801, RABASF; Agustín Esteve, c.1806, portrait as founder of the Instituto Pestalozzi, Museo de Bellas Artes de Valencia; Antonio Carnicero, c.1807-1808, RABASF; José de Madrazo, c.1816, RABASF

nodes.id: María Teresa de Borbón y Vallabriga, XV Condesa de Chinchón
nodes.label: Chinchón
nodes.full name: María Teresa Josefa de Borbón y Vallabriga
nodes.parents: Luis Antonio de Borbón y Farnesio and María Teresa de Vallabriga y Rozas
nodes.children: Carlota Luisa de Godoy y Borbón
nodes.in Paris: she went into exile in 1824, alongside her sister María Luisa and her sister's husband, the Duke of San Fernando de Quiroga. This was due to her links with Constitutionalists and her liberal ideas. She confided her financial affairs to Vicente López Arnao. She was surveyed by the French Police, who knew she had paintings by Velázquez and Murillo (Gerard Powell, 2014, p.306, ANP,F/7 12026)
nodes.art collection: her impressive collection included Velázquez's Cristo de San Plácido, now at the Prado
nodes.sales: she tried to sell her collection in July 1824, then in 1826
nodes.aristocratic titles: XV Countess of Chinchón; I Marchioness of Boadilla del Monte (1799). Grandee of Spain (Grande de España) (1823)
nodes.bibliography: Calvo Ruata 2020; Gerard Powell 2014
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1783, National Gallery, Washington; Goya, 1784, in Retrato del Infante Don Luis (Fundación Magnani-Rocca, Italy); Goya, 1800, Prado

nodes.label: Gaulon
nodes.participates in: the army of the French Republic in 1791
nodes.works as: editor and lithographer for Gustave de Galard, Eugène Devéria, Pierre Lacour, Francisco de Goya y Lucientes (Bulls of Bordeaux, 1825)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, 1824-25, lithography (Harris 1964, no.282)
nodes.bibliography: Harris 1964

nodes.label: Sureda
nodes.in France: 1800-1803 (to study); in 1812, during the Peninsular War (after the Real Fábrica de Porcelana del Buen Retiro is destroyed by the Duke of Wellington)
nodes.in Madrid: from October 1803. He gets portrayed by Goya
nodes.married to: Thérèse Louise Sureda (also portrayed by Goya) [Washington National Gallery of Art 1942.3.1](https://www.nga.gov/artworks/991-therese-louise-de-sureda)
nodes.children: Alejandro Sureda (architect)
nodes.works as: Director of the Real Fábrica de Porcelana del Buen Retiro (until its destruction in 1812 until 1820) and the Real Fábrica de La Moncloa (from 1817); also Director of the Real Fábrica de Paños de Guadalajara and the Real Fábrica de Cristales de La Granja (from 1822)
nodes.portrayed by: Goya, c.1803-04, Washington, National Gallery of Art. According to Sazatornil & Jiméno, Goya made this portrait to thank Sureda for his help with the printing technique of the Caprichos (2014, pp.108-112)
nodes.bibliography: Sazatornil & Jiméno 2014

nodes.label: Matheron
nodes.writes about Goya: first biography of Goya, Goya, 1858, París, Schulz et Thuillié. Digitised in [Prado Biblioteca](https://www.museodelprado.es/aprende/biblioteca/biblioteca-digital/fondo/goya/47f25eaf-29e1-dd74-6727-6227f053e2a2)
nodes.image source: AI generated (DeepAI) because there is no known portrait

nodes.label: Aguado
nodes.Full name: Alejandro María Aguado y Remírez de Estenoz
nodes.profession: banker, military member, collector, art patron
nodes.collection: formed from two collections: that of Bernardo de Iriarte and the Count of Altamira (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.LV). Around 360 paintings, mainly by Spanish artists, including Velázquez, Murillo, Ribera and Zurbarán, as well as Italians like Leonardo da Vinci, Rafael, and Dutch-Flemish like Rubens and Rembrandt
nodes.patronage: acquired the Théâtre-Italien (or Comédie-italienne), funded the journals Revue de Paris and Le Constitutionnel, acted as the President of the Athénée des arts
nodes.portrayed by: Francisco Lacoma y Fontanet, 1832 (Madrid, Museo del Romanticismo, CE0509); unknown artist (Palais de Versailles, MV 6727)
nodes.aristocratic titles: I marqués de las Marismas del Guadalquivir

nodes.label: Villot
collector of Goya's works: Former attribution to Goya, Portrait of a Young Man (c.1820)[1993.1046](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/334587); there is another impression at the BM (ex-Burty)

nodes.label: Devéria
nodes.works as: director of the Département des Estampes at the BNF in 1849
nodes.address: 45 rue de Nôtre Dame des Champs (1833)

nodes.label: Nanteuil
nodes.profession: painter, draughtsman, lithographer (etching, lithography, woodcut), illustrator, museum curator
author of: Covers for his friends: Théophile Gautier's Albertus and Les Jeunes-France; four covers for the edition of Victor Hugo's works (1832); Alexandre Dumas père's Impressions de voyage, Angèle and the 1st edition of Théâtre.
Contributes to the illustrations of Furne's edition of the work of Honoré de Balzac.
Advertisement for Honoré Daumier's Cent et un Robert-Macaire (1839).

Lithography: Rabelais (1836) after Eugène Delacroix; reproductions after Titian, José de Ribera, Velázquez and others to illustrate an anthology of paintings of the Royal Museum in Madrid (Prado) by Juan José Martínez (Madrid, 1857).
Woodcut illustrations in the 1840s.
Paintings: he was awarded at the Salon in 1837, 1848, 1861 and 1867. An example is Un rayon de soleil (1848, Musée de Valenciennes).
nodes.studied in: École nationale supérieure des beaux-arts de Paris (from 1827)
nodes.works as: director of the Académie des Beaux-arts (1867); curator at the Musée des Beaux-arts de Dijon
nodes.founder of: the journal Les Artistes contemporains (1843-1847) with lithographers Eugène Prosper Leroux, Adolphe Mouilleron, and painters Henri Baron and Louis Français
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1868)
nodes.curiosities: his parents belonged to the circle of Joseph Bonaparte. Hoplessly in love with famous actress Marie Dorval
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, 1873 (photograph)
nodes.bibliography: Henri Béraldi, 1890, 'Les graveurs du XIXe siècle : guide de l'amateur d'estampes modernes', Paris, L. Conquet

nodes.label: Fontaney
nodes.in Spain: 1830-1831, accompanying the Duke d'Harcourt (Eugène d'Harcourt), ambassador of France in Spain
nodes.works as: secretary of the French embassy in Madrid [1830]
nodes.author of: Ballades, mélodies et poésies diverse (1829); <'Scènes de la vie castillane et andalouse' (article series in Revue des Deux Mondes)
shows Goya: 8 Sept 1831: 'Evening at l'Arsenal; Mélanie, Louise [Soulié] were there. I showed them the Goya' (ed. Jasinski 1925, p.31).

9 Nov 1831, at Belloc's: 'I am going to Mmes Belloc [Louise Swanton-Belloc], Mlle de Montgolfier [Adélaïde de Montgolfier]. (...) (Auguste) Blanqui the conspirator with a long white beard, (Jean-Alexandre) Plocque; (Auguste) Barthélémy;--a fat man who states in regard to Goya: It is not lacking in verve' (p.71).
nodes.partners/lovers: Gabrielle Dorval (daughter of the actress Marie Dorval). They flee together to Spain and England (where he falls sick with phthisis)
nodes.pseudonyms: Lord Feeling (from the Scottish writer Henry Mackenzie)
nodes.curiosities: He was (unhappily) in love with Marie Nodier. After dying of phthisis, both Hugo and Sainte-Beuve forget their recent fallout and attend his funeral
nodes.bibliography: Fontaney's journal: Fontaney-Jasinski 1925

nodes.label: Hugo
nodes.profession: author, essayist, novelist, playwright, poet, politician
author of: Art criticism: Preface of Cromwell (play) (1827).
Poetry: Les Orientales (1829): illustrated by Louis Boulanger; Les Feuilles d'automne (1831); Torquemada (1869).
Plays: Hernani (1830): takes place in Spain; Marion Delorme (1831); Le roi s'amuse (1832: forbidden); Ruy Blas (1838).
Novels: Le Dernier jour d'un condamné (1829); Notre-Dame de Paris (1831); Les Misérables (1862).
nodes.works as: Peer of France (1845-48); Member of the National Assembly for Seine (1848-51); Member of the National Assembly for Gironde (1871); Senator for Seine (1876-1882)
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members George Sand, Alexandre Dumas and Honoré de Balzac. Académie française (1841-1885)
nodes.political views: as a Pair de France in the Upper Chamber of Parliament (1845), he spoke against the death penalty and social injustice, and in favour of freedom of the press and self-government for Poland. With Napoleon III's seize of power in 1851, he declared him a traitor to France and moved to Brussels, then Jersey, then the Channel Islands, where he was in exile 1855-1870. However, he justified colonialism in terms of a civilising mission, although he was an abolitionist of slavery. During the Paris Commune, he was very critical of both sides. He was also famously anticlerical.
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Alaux (1825; Maison Victor Hugo 253); Achille Devéria, lithograph (1829); Charles Hugo, photograph (c.1853-55); Étienne Carjat, photograph, 1875
nodes.studies in: Real Colegio de San Antonio de Abad (Madrid); Lycée Louis le Grand (Paris)
nodes.children: Léopold Hugo, Léopoldine Hugo, Charles Hugo, François-Victor Hugo, Adèle Hugo
nodes.parents: Joseph Léopold Hugo and Sophie Trébuchet
nodes.curiosities: on 10 July 1816, he wrote in his diary: 'I shall be Chateaubriand or nothing'. He frequented spiritism during his exile, and participated in séances conducted by Madame Delphine de Girardin (Delphine Gay). When asked in 1872 if he was a Catholic, he answered, 'No. A Freethinker'. Notre-Dame de Paris was listed as a 'forbidden book' by the Church.

nodes.label: Gautier
nodes.address: Hôtel de Fourcy (1828-1834); impasse du Doyenné (current Place du Carrousel), near Camille Rogier, Arsène Houssaye and Nerval. He shares an apartment with Eguène Piot
nodes.partners/lovers: Carlotta Grisi (dancer), who leads in Gautier's ballet Giselle (1842)
nodes.children: Théophile Gautier fils, Judith Gautier, Estelle Gautier
nodes.parents: Jean-Pierre Gautier and Adélaïde Cocard
author of: Essays: Les Jeunes-France (1833); 1840 Spanish trip essays in La Presse, reedited as Tra los montes (1843) and as Voyage en Espagne (1845). 1843 August: Gautier, ‘La Tauromachie’, Le Musée des familles, pp. 341–48.13 Illustrated with seven drawings by Gautier (signed ‘T. G.’) engraved by ‘A.B.L’ (Andrew, Best and Leloir) (see Fayos Pérez 2024); Histoire du romantisme (1874). A volume of articles published as Les Grotesques. A biography of Honoré de Balzac. Art criticism: musicians (Berlioz, Gounod, Wagner) and painters (Delacroix, Manet, Gustave Doré, Théodore Chasséirau, Goya).
Fiction: La Cafetière (1831); Mademoiselle de Maupin (1835); Militona (1847), set in Madrid; Les deux étoiles (184); Roman de la momie (1857); Capitaine Fracasse (1861-63)
Poetry: La Comédie de la Mort (1838); España (1845); Poésies complètes (1845); Émaux et Camées (1852)
Theatre: Une larme au diable (1839)
Libretti: Giselle (ballet; 1841)
nodes.trips: Belgium and Holland (1836: with Nerval); Spain (1840); Algeria (1845); Spain (1846); Italy (1850); Greece and Turkey (1852); Russia (1858); Egypt (1869)
mentions of Goya: 1831-IX-8 Albertus
1832-VIII-5, Onophrius Wphly, La France littéraire, pp.388-418: 'El sueno de la razon produce monstruos. Goya' (Capricho 43)

1834 preface of Mademoiselle de Maupin: 'Quant au genre monstre, vous savez comme ils l’ont traité (...) Ni les grands traits à la Michel-Ange, ni les curiosités dignes de Callot, ni les effets d’ombre et de clair à la façon de Goya, rien n’a pu trouver grâce devant eux' (pp.34-35)
1838-VII-5, Les Caprices de Goya; (La Presse): mentions Goya's Album B of drawings?
1842 ‘Franco Goya y Lucientes’, Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 337–45 (with Valentín Carderera's help [Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.550]).
1845 mentions Disasters of War (Voyage en Espagne, nouvelle édition révue, p.136) [quoted by Valentín Carderera in 1863] (Fayos Pérez 2024).

1855 Les Beaux-arts en Europe: 'L'Espagne a oublié Velasquez, Ribera, Murillo, Zurbaran et même Goya; elle ne peint plus avec sa sombre palette d'autrefois des moines au froc brun [...] elle n'a plus cette ardeur farouche, cette passion catholique qui la caractérisaient [...]' (p.8)

1874 Histoire du romantisme: 'Victor Hugo, s’il n’était pas poète, serait un peintre de premier ordre ; il excelle à mêler, dans des fantaisies sombres et farouches, les effets de clair-obscur de Goya à la terreur architecturale de Piranèse'; '[...] cette entente des terreurs nocturnes qu’on ne rencontre que dans les Caprices de Goya'; '[Louis Boulanger] Tantôt c’était Rubens, tantôt c’était Véronèse, et puis Titien ; d’autres fois, franchissant les monts, il allait à Velasquez et à Goya'.
in Spain: He first knows Spain through Alfred de Musset's Contes d'Espagne et d'Italie (1829) and Victor Hugo's Les Orientales (1829)
In 1840, with Eugène Piot, watches Hugo's Hernani (translated by Eugenio Ochoa; Gautier praises the translation)
In 1846, invited by Louis-Philippe, to the wedding of the Duke of Montpensier with the Infanta Luisa Fernanda
nodes.studies in: Lycée Louis-le-Grand (1820); Lycée Charlemagne, where he meets Gérard de Nerval (Gérard Labrunie)
nodes.writes in: La Chronique de Paris, La Presse (of Émile Girardin) (editor until 1855), L'Artiste, Le Moniteur universel (from 1855), Le cabinet de l'amateur, Le Figaro, L'Univers illustré, Revue nationale et étrangère
nodes.decorations/awards: Officier de La Légion d'honneur
nodes.member of: Société héliographique (1851); Jeune-France; Société nationale des beaux-arts
nodes.participates in: the Battle of Hernani (1830); Les Français peints par eux-mêmes (1840)
nodes.knows Goya's works: the Caprichos: in late 1830-late 1831 (Lipschutz 1972, p.118); through Antoine Fontaney? (brought a Caprichos set in January 1831); Goya's drawings by 1838 (Fayos Pérez 2024)
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Bulls of Bordeaux; Tauromaquia (lot 66, 24-25 Feb 1873 sale): sold Sotheby's Paris, 14 Dec 2022, lot 37 (showing Valentín Carderera's dedicatory to Gautier); Tauromaquia set given by Valentín Carderera on 13 Nov 1859 (Lanzarote Guiral 2016, p.431)
nodes.portrayed by: Auguste de Châtillon, 1839, Musée Carnavalet (oil painting); Bertall, 1850 (photograph); Amédée Bodin after Théodore Chassériau, 1850 (drawing); Nadar, 1850 (photograph); Nadar, 1854-55, Getty (photograph); Nadar, 1855 (photograph); Nadar, 1856 (photograph); Albert-Ernest Carrier-Belleuse, 1862 (sculpture: bust); Hippolite Mailly, 1862 (caricature); André Gill, 1869, L'éclipse (caricature)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Lanzarote Guiral 2016; Lacoste-Veysseyre 2014; Hovasse 2001; Moulinat 1995; Lacoste-Veysseyre 1982; Delesalle 1982

nodes.label: Balzac
nodes.author of: La Comédie humaine (1831-50), including La peau du chagrin (1831), which mentions Murillo and Velázquez; Le Chef-d'œuvre inconnu (1831); Les Cent Contes drolatiques (1832-37); Eugénie Grandet (1834); Le Père Goriot (1835).
nodes.participates in: Les français peints par eux-mêmes (1840) (ed. Léon Curmer), alongside Théophile Gautier, Alexandre Dumas, J. J. Grandville, Honoré Daumier and Paul Gavarni; J. J. Grandville's Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (1842), alongside Charles Nodier and George Sand.
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas and George Sand
nodes.works as: President of the Société des gens de lettres (1839-1840)
nodes.masters: François Guizot; Abel-François Villemain; Victor Cousin
nodes.political views: ambiguous. A legitimist during the July Revolution (1830). He declares himself a liberal. Defends the working class. While expressing some conservative ideas, his work was admired by Marx and Engels, and reflects some elements close to Anarchism.
nodes.writes in: Revue des Deux Mondes, La Presse, Le Constitutionnel, Le Siècle
nodes.studies in: Lycée Charlemagne (1814-18); Sorbonne Université (from 1816); Faculté de Droit (1816-19)
nodes.pseudonyms: Horace de Saint-Aubin, Lord R’Hoone, Viellerglé, Saint Aubin
nodes.portrayed by: Louis-Auguste Bisson, 1842, daguerrotype
nodes.partners/lovers: Henirette de Maillé de La Tour-Landry; Laure de Berny (1823-1833); Olympe Pélissier; Maria du Fresnay (desde 1833); Caroline Marbouty (1833-1839)
nodes.parents: Bernard-François Balzac and Anne-Charlotte-Laure Sallambier
nodes.children: Marie-Caroline du Fresnay
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'Honneur (1845)

nodes.label: Dumas
nodes.author of: Henri III et sa cour (1829) (play); Les Trois Mousquetaires (1844) (novel); Le Comte de Monte-Cristo (1844-46) (novel); La Reine Margot (1845)
mentions of Goya: 1837-V-28 28 ‘[…] Goya, ce fantaisiaque [sic] élève de Tiepolo le Vénitien, avec lequel est mort la grande peinture espagnole, et qui dans ses compositions, dont la vérité a fait des satires, a tout attaqué: moines, nobles et rois’ (p. 2). About the Galerie espagnole: ‘[…] doté la France d’un trésor qui allait être perdu pour le monde, et rapporté pour 800,000 francs, quatre cents tableaux qui valent trois millions’ (p. 2) ‘Feuilleton: M. le Baron Taylor en Espagne’, La Presse, 1–2 [digitised in Gallica]

1845-I-16 'C’était un spectacle à la fois lugubre et bizarre, que tous ces élégans [sic] seigneurs et toutes ces belles dames défilant comme une procession, peinte par Goya, au milieu de ces squelettes noircis et de ces gibets aux longs bras décharnés’ (‘Feuilleton: La Reine Margot, second volume’, La Presse, pp.1–3) [digitised in Gallica]

1849-V-3 ‘On dirait une de ces gravures de Goya, où, dans la demi-teinte, des arracheurs de dents font la chasse aux pendus’ (‘Feuilleton: Les mille et un fantomes’, Le Constitutionnel, p.1) [digitised in Gallica] (see Fayos Pérez 2024).
nodes.in Spain: October 1846 to January 1847, accompanied by his son Alexandre and his collaborator Auguste Maquet. In the same trip he goes to Algeria
nodes.portrayed by: Joseph Guichard, 1828 (Louvre); Achille Devéria, c.1829; Achille Devéria, c.1832 (lithography published by Charles Motte); Cham, 1846 (caricature); Gouin, 1852 (photograph); Nadar, 1855 (photograph); William Henry Powell, 1855 (oil); Gustave Le Gray, c.1859 (photograph); Cham, 1860 (caricature); André Gill, 2 Dec 1866 (caricature); Alphonse Liébert, 1867 (photograph).
nodes.parents: Marie-Louise Labouret and Thomas Alexandre Davy de La Pailleterie
nodes.children: Alexandre Dumas fils; Henry Bauër
nodes.bibliography: Dumas-Schopp 2014

nodes.label: Nodier
nodes.writes in: La Quotidienne (1821-1830): he presents the work of Walter Scott, Rabelais, Marot, Lamartine, Byron and Victor Hugo; Revue des Deux Mondes; Revue de Paris (from 1829)
nodes.participates in: J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Honoré de Balzac and George Sand
nodes.political views: favourable to the French Revolution (Société des amis de la Constitution; Club des Jacobins), but also Royalist. Essentially against despotic power.
nodes.works as: librarian of the comte d'Artois, future Charles X. He lives at the Arsenal (Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal), where he holds a literary salon known as a 'cénacle' (mentioned by Dumas as a place where all the big names of Romantic literature were present). Dismissed by Polignac in July 1830, then reinstated by Louis-Philippe when the Library passed to the state in August.
nodes.portrayed by: Paulin Guérin; lithograph in Cénacle de la Muse française (1827)
nodes.author of: Smarra ou les Démons de la nuit (1821): of massive influence in the Romantic generation; Infernalia (1822); Trillby ou le lutin d'Argail (1822); Examen critique des dictionnaires de la langue française (1828); Le Vieux Marinier (1832).
nodes.editor of: Adèle, Mélanges de littérature et de critique and Lord Ruthwen ou les Vampires by Cyprien Bérard
nodes.founder of: the Bulletin du bibliophile, with the bookseller Techener (whose collection included a set of Goya's Caprichos in the 1841 sale)
nodes.children: Marie Antoinette Mennessier-Nodier
nodes.parents: Antoine-Melchior Nodier (speaker: oratorien)
nodes.member of: Académie française (1833-44); Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Besançon et de Franche-Comté; Société nationale des antiquaires de France
nodes.masters: Justin Girod de Chantrans (botanique, entomologie, minéralogie); Euloge Schneider (Greek); Joseph Droz
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier de la Légion d'honneur (1822)
nodes.curiosities: in 1797 he was member of a secret society called the Philadelphes. Later, he was a member of the 4th society of Caveau (1834-39) ('société bachique'), dedicated to drinking, singing and literature.

nodes.label: Custine
nodes.author of: 1838, 17 June (Le Temps) essay on Goya's works (signed as 'A. de C.')
nodes.mentions of Goya: Letter to Miss Bowles (13 April 1831): 'Un peintre espagnol moderne, Goya, mérite d’être cité, surtout pour ses portraits. En mourant il a emporté la gloire et le secret de l’école de son pays. Sa manière tenait à la fois de celle de Velasquez et de celle de Murillo'; 1838 essay ('A. de C.'): Goya's Caprichos, Disasters of War, Bulls of Bordeaux, Familia Carlos IV, frescoes and Black paintings (Fayos Pérez 2025: publication pending)

nodes.label: Montgolfier
nodes.knows Goya's works: by April 1831, through Fontaney (after his return from Spain in Jan 1831)
nodes.writes about Goya: In April 1831: signed as 'Ad. M' (Revue encyclopédique no.50, pp.316-331). Parts of her essay are plagiarised by male writers such as Gustave Brunet (1855, Revue Universelle des Arts) and Théophile Thoré (10 Sept 1842)
nodes.author of: she co-authored with Louise Swanton Belloc a number of children's books (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.founder of: La Ruche, journal d'études familière (with Louise Swanton Belloc), a monthly magazine dedicated to the education of young women (Buell Hale 1874, p.583-84)
nodes.curiosities: her father was the famous aeronaut Jacques-Etienne Montgolfier. She was buried alongside her close friend Louise Swanton Belloc (and her son, Louis Belloc) at La Celle-Saint-Cloud
nodes.bibliography: Sarah Josepha Buell Hale, Woman's Record: Or, Sketches of All Distinguished Women, 1874. Google books [https://books.google.es/books?id=X7ZiAAAAMAAJ&vq=belloc+la+ruche&hl=es&source=gbs_navlinks_s]

nodes.label: Delphine Gay
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, poet, novelist, playwright, salonnière, journalist
nodes.salon: at Hôtel Marbeuf. Attendants: Théophile Gautier, Honoré de Balzac, Alfred de Musset, Victor Hugo, George Sand, Alphonse de Lamartine, Alexandre Dumas, Franz Liszt, Jules Janin, Fortunée Hamelin. Circle of Charles Nodier
nodes.author of: Essais poétiques (1824), Nouveaux Essais poétiques (1825), Napoline (1833); Lettres parisiennes (1843). Fiction: Le Lorgnon (1832), Le Marquis de Pontanges (1835), Contes d'une vieille fille à ses neveux (1832), La Canne de Monsieur Balzac (1836), Il ne faut pas jouer avec la douleur (1853). Drames en prose: L'Ecole des journalists (1840), Judith (1843), Lady Tartuffe (1853). Comedies: C'est la faute du mari (1851), La joie fait peur (1854), Une femme qui déteste son mari (posthumous)
nodes.in Italy: in 1827, where she is enthusiastically welcomed in the Roman literary circle and crowned in the Capitol
nodes.pseudonyms: Vicomte Charles Delaunay, Charles de Launay, Vicomte de Launay, Léo Lespès, Léa Sepsel, Émile de Girardin
nodes.parents: Sophie Gay and Jean Sigismond Gay
nodes.portrayed by: Louis Hersent, 1824, château de Versailles (oil painting); LD, 'Une muse en 1848', Le Charivari, 15 December 1848 (caricature); anonymous, 1855 (photograph)
nodes.curiosities: her mother named her Delphine because of the homonymous novel by Madame de Staël

nodes.label: Desbordes-Valmore
nodes.author of: Poésies; Les Pleurs (poems; 1833); Violette (novel); L'Atelier d'un peintre (1833; autobiography)
nodes.member of: Académie des sciences, belles-lettres et arts de Lyon (1835)
nodes.works in: théâtre de l'Odéon; Opéra-Comique; théâtre de la Monnaie (Brussels), where she plays Rosina in Le Barbier de Séville (1815)
nodes.decorations/awards: Prix Lambert (1859)
nodes.portrayed by: Constant Joseph Desbordes, Douai, Musée de la Chartreuse, c.1811 (oil painting); Baugé, 1833 (lithograph); Nadar, 1854 (photograph)
nodes.parents: Catherine Lucas and Félix Desbordes
nodes.children: Louisa Desbordes, Marie-Eugène Desbordes, Junie Valmore, Hippolyte Valmore, Ondine Valmore, Inès Valmore

nodes.label: Hortense Allart
nodes.works as: governess in the household of General Bertrand
nodes.political views: enthusiastic supporter of Napoleon. She offered to travel to Saint Helena to nurse the former emperor
nodes.author of: Essai sur la religion intérieure (1824); Lettres sur les ouvrages de Madame de Staël (1824); Jerome (1829; novel): about her relations with Sampayo; Settimia (novel; 1836); La femme et la démocratie de nos temps (1836); Les enchantements de Prudence, Avec George Sand (1873): it had a 'succès de scandale'
nodes.partners/lovers: Comte de Sampayo; Gino Capponi?; George Sand?; François-René de Chateaubriand; Henry Bulwer Lytton (Lord Dalling)
nodes.married to: Napoléon Louis Frédéric Corneille de Méritens de Malvézie (1843: only one year)
nodes.children: Marcus
nodes.parents: Nicolas-Jean-Gabriel Allart and Marie-Françoise Gay
nodes.portrayed by: Sophie Allart (her sister), Rome, 1829, Châtenay-Malabry, Maison de chateaubriand (oil painting)
nodes.curiosities: her mother translated the works of English gothic author Ann Radcliffe

nodes.label: Amable Tastu
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, poet, libretist
nodes.author of: poetry; pedagogical works; translations; Cours d'histoire de France (1837); a volume about German literature; a volume about Italian literature
nodes.works as: libretist for musicians such as Saint-Saëns (La Feuille de peuplier, Plainte, 1853)
nodes.member of: Société linnéenne de Paris (1822)
nodes.married to: Joseph Tastu (1816): works in the liberal publisher of the brothers Beaudouin, 36, rue de Vaugirard
nodes.parents: Jacques-Philippe Voïart and Jeanne-Amable Bouchotte; Anne Élisabeth Élise Petitpain (stepmother): femme de lettres at Nancy
nodes.children: Eugène
nodes.portrayed by: Constance Mayer, 1817, Metz, Musée de la Cour d'Or (oil on canvas)
nodes.curiosities: she was considered the Romantic muse par excelence. After her husband's death, she follows her son to his diplomatic missions in Cyprus and Bagdad. The rose 'Amable Tastu' was created in 1851 in her honour; with the initiative of the 'Amis d'Amable Tastu', a new 'Rose Amable' was created in 2018

nodes.label: Marie Nodier
nodes.profession: femme de lettres, writer, novelist, composer, poet
nodes.author of: Sonnet à Mélanie Gaume (1830); Mélodies romantiques (1831); 'Lettres d'une hirondelle à une serine élevée au Couvent des oiseaux', in J. J. Grandville's Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux (1842); Charles Nodier, épisodes et souvenirs de sa vie (1867)
nodes.correspondence: vol. 1 (1821-1848), II (1849-1892), III (Lettres à Marie), in 2019, 2020 and 2021 respectively
nodes.portrayed by: Jean Gigoux, Musée de Besançon, 902.6.1 (oil painting); Hyppolyte Masson, 1838, coll. Mennessier-Nodier (drawing)
nodes.children: Georgette, Emmanuel, Thècle, Marie-Victoire
nodes.parents: Charles Nodier and Désirée Charve
nodes.curiosities: a royal order allows them in 1844 to name their children 'Mennessier-Nodier'

nodes.label: George Sand
nodes.profession: writer, novelist, journalist, salonnière, art critic, playwright, libretist, composer
nodes.in Spain: 1808-1809 her family lived in Spain at the palace of Manuel Godoy when this one was exiled in Paris
nodes.mentions of Goya: Journal intime, 25 Nov 1834 (jealousy over Goya's women regarding Alfred de Musset)
nodes.author of: Voyage chez Mr. Blaise (1829); Voyage en Auvergne (1829); Voyage en Espagne (1829); Un hiver en Majorque (1841); La Petite Fadette (1849); Histoire de ma vie (1855). Album of drawings. Clumsy copy of Velázquez’s Infanta Margarita. Collection Lovenjoul Chantily [now at Institut de France? (Lipschutz 1972, p.117)
nodes.participates in: J. J. Grandville's 'Scènes de la vie privée et publique des animaux' (1842), alongside Charles Nodier and Honoré de Balzac.
nodes.member of: Société des gens de lettres (founded by Louis Desnoyer), of which were also members Victor Hugo, Alexandre Dumas and Honoré de Balzac.
nodes.parents: Maurice Dupin de Francueil and Sophie Victoire Delaborde
nodes.partners/lovers: Prosper Mérimée; Jules Sandeau; Alfred de Musset (1833-35); Félicien Mallefille; Hortense Allart?; Marie Dorval?; Frédéric Chopin; Victor Borie (1848-49); Alexandre Manceau (1849-64)
nodes.children: Maurice Sand; Solange Sand

nodes.label: Burty
nodes.profession: art critic, art collector, artist, lithographer, draughtsman
nodes.works as: art critic in different journals; inspector at the Académie des Beaux-Arts (1881); art dealer and advisor for art dealers such as Frederick Keppel
nodes.member of: Société des aquafortistes (founded in 1862), directed by Alfred Cadart; Union centrale des beaux-arts appliqués à l’industrie
nodes.parents: father: Marin Burty, silk merchant and owner of fashion business during the Restoration
nodes.masters: Chabal Dussurgey, painter of flowers at the Gobelins manufactory
nodes.children: Madeleine (who marries the porcelain maker Charles Edward Haviland)
editor of: Illustrated albums: Sonnets et eaux-fortes (1869), edited by Alphonse Lemerre, gathering 42 painters-engravers and 42 poets; L'Eau-forte en... (1874-1881, ed. Alfred Cadart) [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b8527609t); Japonisme (1883), a series of prints by Félix Buhot, from the Burty collection (Paris, Edmond Sagot); L'Âge du romantisme, illustrated album edited with Maurice Tourneux (Monnier, 1887)

Art criticism: La Photographie au Palais des beaux-arts (1859); Catalogue de tableaux et dessins de l'école française, principalement du XVIIIe siècle, tirés de collections d'amateurs (1860); Chefs-d'oeuvre des arts industriels (1866); Notice des études peintes par M. Théodore Rousseau exposées au Cercle des arts (1867); Les émaux cloisonnés anciens et modernes (1868); Eaux-fortes de Jules de Goncourt : notice et catalogue (1876); Maîtres et petits maîtres (1877). He writes, among many other artists, about Degas, Gustave Moreau, Puvis de Chavannes, Jules Bastien-Lepage, Camille Pissarro, Théodore Rousseau, Pierre Paul Prud'hon, Millet
The correspondence of Eugène Delacroix: 1st edition, 1878 [Gallica](https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k205063z); 2nd edition, revised and expanded, 1880
nodes.author of: Les Émaux cloisonnés anciens et modernes (1868); Maîtres et Petits Maîtres (1872); essay on Edgar Degas exhibition, 'Fine Art: The Exhibition of the Intransigeants', Academy, 15 April 1876; Grave Imprudence (1880, novel)
nodes.writes in: Gazette des Beaux-arts (since 1859); Le Rappel (in 1871 during the Paris Commune)
nodes.political views: 'Dedicated Republican and networker'; 'herald of modernity and stimulated reflections on the renewal of the arts in France' (AGORHA). During the Paris Commune in 1871, he wrote in Le Rappel and supported Gustave Courbet's Fédération des artistes
nodes.portrayed by: Étienne Carjat, 1873, photograph; Carolus-Duran, 1874, oil painting, Allen Memorial Art Museum (Ohio); Marcellin-Gilbert Desboutin, 1875, drawing, BNF, Dép. Estampes, FOL-EF-415 (I, 1)
sales: Burty II: 27 March 1874 (lot 14: 2 black pencil drawings by Delacroix after Goya, 13 fr.)

Burty III: 27 April 1876 (Sotheby's London; 56 lots of Goya (nos.444-465, 684-719), which included Caprichos, Tauromaquia, Proverbios (Disparates), and a working-proof edition of Disasters of War as lot 465 (British Museum [1876,1111.335](https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/P_1876-1111-335). In 1877, Théophile Gautier asked to see Burty's working-proof set of the Disasters (Delesalle 1983, p.104), but this set was acquired the year before, in 1876
Burty V (2-3 March 1891): lot 83 4 pen drawings by Delacroix after Goya
Burty VI (4-5 March 1891): Tauromaquia, Desastres, Proverbios, Agarrotado, drawing
nodes.collection: Charles Meryon, Goya, Théophile Chauvel, Michel Manzi, Félix Bracquemond, Eugène Delacroix, Decamps, Édouard Manet, Gericault, (school of) Rembrandt (drawing Landscape with Two Mills, Met 41.21.1), Millet, Jacquemart
collector of Goya's works: Burty acquired 11 sheets of drawings by Delacroix after Goya at the Delacroix sale in 1864: lot 640 'Études d'après Goya: onze feuilles de croquis' (Robaut 1885, p.476, no.1962). Those that have been located are catalogued in Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III

The Metropolitan Museum holds several prints by Goya that belonged to the Burty collection: from Disparates, 'Funereal Folly' (private printing c.1854) [31.79.2](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333961), 'Flying Folly' (private printing c.1854) [32.78.3](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333981), 'Dancing Giant' (private printing c.1854) [31.79.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/397761), another 'Dancing Giant' (published 1854-63) [21.54.1](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333833), 'Folly of Fear' (published c.1848) [21.54.2](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333834); A Maja standing against a dark background with figures, 1859 [23.37.6](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333866), The cloaked man (1859) [23.37.5](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333865); La Tauromaquia (1816) [21.19.1-34](https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/333828); a former attribution to Goya, Portrait of a Young Man (c.1820) (British Museum; another impression at the Metropolitan, ex-Villot

The British Museum holds [29 prints and drawings](https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/search?keyword=Goya&keyword=Burty) by or after Goya from the Burty collection (Burty sales II and III), including a drawing by Delacroix after Goya (see Fayos Pérez 2024, Appendix III, D34, p.464)
curiosities: He was the grandfather of the photographer Paul Haviland and of the painter Frank Burty Haviland
nodes.decorations/awards: medal of the Order of the Rising Sun (1884): a rare honor for a non-Japanese person (INHA)
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; P. Weisberg, The Independent Critic: Philippe Burty and the Visual Arts of Mid-Nineteenth-Century France, 1993; Delesalle 1983; P. Weisberg, The Early Years of Philippe Burty: Art Critic, Amateur and Japoniste, 1855-1875, 1967; Robaut 1885

nodes.label: Bracquemond
nodes.considered as: promoter of the study of Japanese art in France, from 1856; also of the interest in printmaking, encouraging artists such as Édouard Manet, Edgar Degas and Camille Pissarro to use this technique (Monneret 1987, p.74)
nodes.registered in: the Cabinet des estampes (BNF) as reader in 1849, alongside Henri Fantin-Latour and Gustave Doré (Lethève 1968, p.109)
member of: Société nationale des beaux-arts (1890): he encourages foreign artists (particularly Japanese) to exhibit at the Salon des beaux-arts
Société anonyme des artistes peintres, sculpteurs et graveurs: from 1874
Société des peintres-graveurs français: honorary president (1890)
Société des peintres-lithographes: honorary president (with his friend Auguste Rodin)
participates in: The Salon: 1852 with Portrait de ma grand-mère (compared to Hans Holbein the Younger by Théophile Gautier); 1853 with Autoportrait with his printmaking tools

Première exposition des peintres impressionnistes (1874): at Nadar's workshop. He presents a drawing portrait, etching portraits of Auguste Comte, Baudelaire and Théophile Gautier, etchings after Turner, Ingres and Manet, and original etchings like Les Saules and Le Mur. He exhibits again with the Impressionists in 1879 and 1880 (Portrait d'Edmond de Goncourt)
nodes.founder of: L'Estampe original with Auguste Lepère, Daniel Vierge and Tony Beltrand. From the 1870s he was thinking of creating a journal focused on printmaking with Degas, Camille Pissarro and Mary Cassatt
nodes.friends: Edmond de Goncourt; Charles Baudelaire; Théodore de Banville; Jules Barbery d'Aurevilly; Félix Nadar; Édouard Manet; James McNeill Whistler; Henri Fantin-Latour (Bracquemond appears in his Hommage à Delacroix (1864, Orsay); Auguste Rodin
nodes.works as: ceramist and designer at the Manufacture nationale de Sèvres (from 1870); artistic director at the workshop of Charles Edward Haviland in Limoges
nodes.parents: César Auguste Bracquemond and Jeanne Girardine Bailly
nodes.married to: Marie Bracquemond, née Marie Quivoron (1869), Impressionist painter
nodes.children: Pierre Bracquemond
nodes.masters: Joseph Guichard (student of Ingres); Théodore Deck
nodes.students: Alexandre Jean-Baptiste Brun; Louis Busière; François Courboin; Léon Coutil; Édouard Dammouse; Lucien Dautrey; Fernand Desmoulin; Jeanne Sisley; Henri Jean Turlin
nodes.decorations/awards: Chevalier (1882) Officier de la Légion d'honneur (1889). Médaille d'honneur du Salon (1884)
nodes.copies after Goya: Don Quixote (F.54), 1860, for Carderera's article in Gazette des Beaux-arts (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.164, fig.II.42)
author of: Portraits: Paul Meurice, Charles Méryon (1853), Alphonse Legros (1861), Zacharie Astruc (c.1865), Édouard Manet (1864, pastel), Edmond de Goncourt (1882)
After other artists: Jean-Louis-Ernest Meissonier, Gustave Moreau, Jean-Baptiste Camille Corot, Eugène Delacroix (Les Natchez, 1835, Met)

Original compositions: Broderie (c.1855), L'Inconnu (1862), L'éclipse (1869), La Terrasse de la villa Brancas (1876), Le grand lapin (1891), Roseaux et sarcelles (1882), Les Hirondelles (1882), Les Mouettes (1888)
Essays: Du dessin et de la couleur (1886), very appreciated by Vincent van Gogh (Monneret 1987, p.76); Étude sur la gravure sur bois et la lithographie
nodes.portrayed by: Nadar, 1865, photograph
nodes.bibliography: Jean-Paul Bouillon, Félix Bracquemond et les arts décoratifs, 2005; Monneret, L'Impressionnisme et son époque, 1987; Lethève 1968; Henri Beraldi, 'Félix Bracquemont', in Les Graveurs du XIXe siècle. nodes.label: Piot
nodes.profession: art critic; collector; editor; journalist; photographer
nodes.trips: 1838, first trip to Italy; 1840 to Spain; 1868-1881 several trip to Egypt; Greece
nodes.collection: started around 1838 during a trip to Italy. His interest in the arts started in relation to his friend Théophile Gautier. He acquired objects at the sales of Pourtalès (1865), Barre (1878) and Paravey (1879) (see Garnery 2023)
nodes.author of: 'Catalogue raisonné de l’œuvre gravé de Fran(co) Goya y Lucientes', Le Cabinet de l’Amateur, 1842 (pp.346-366): Caprichos (80), Tauromaquia (33), Disasters of War (‘Scènes d’invasion’) (20/82), prints after Velázquez (14), Pièces diverses (Garrotted Man), Lithographs (Bulls of Bordeaux) (6); L'Italie monumentale (1851): photographic album (for which he receives an award at the Exposition universelle 1855)
nodes.editor of: Le Cabinet de l'amateur et de l'antiquaire (1842-1846)
nodes.sales: 12 April 1847: Caprichos (bought by 'Bauzonnet'?), Tauromaquia (lots 29-30); 1848; 1850; 1857 and 1858 (dedicated to Egyptian, Greek and Roman antiquities); 1864; 1870; 1876; 1885, 22 rare proofs of Caprichos with handwritten inscriptions, acquired by BNF [Fayos Pérez 2024, p.55]; 1890 (posthumous)
nodes.mentions of the Prado commentaries: On his catalogue raisonné 1842 (Capricho 50):  Carderera’s diary (2 August 1861) shows he lent them to Piot, but he must have known them by 1842, having copied them in Madrid, or during one of Madrazo’s trips to Paris?
nodes.founder of: Le Cabinet de l'Amateur, illustrated by artists such as Eugène Delacroix and Ernest Meissonnier
nodes.member of: Société de l’histoire de France (1843); Société de l’histoire de Paris et de l’Île-de-France (1874-1881); Société nationale des antiquaires de France (1843); l’Institut archéologique de Rome (1865); Académie de Saint-Ferdinand [RABASF?] (1873)
nodes.address: Impasse du Doyenné, from 1835-36 (sharing an apartment with Théophile Gautier); 20, rue Saint-Fiacre; 64, rue de Courcelles (after 1860)
nodes.decorations/awards: he receives an award (médaille de première classe) at the Exposition universelle 1855 for the photographic album entitled L'Italie monumentale (1851)
nodes.curiosities: in his 1840 trip to Spain, Piot took photographs of the Burgos cathedral. There was a Prix Eugène Piot at the Académie des Beaux-Arts (established in his will in 1889) until 1984
nodes.bibliography: Garnery 2023; Bonnafé 1890; Piot 1999; Courajod 1890

Navarro in 'Arte compacto', episode on José de Madrazo, 27 April 2025).

nodes.label: Brunet
nodes.author of: Fantaisies bibliographiques (1864)
writes about Goya: 1855 Review of Charles Le Blanc’s Manuel de l’amateur d’estampes (Paris, P. Jannet), where Brunet laments the absence of Goya’s Tauromaquia (33 plates) and Scènes d’invasion (i.e. Disasters of War; 20 known plates). ‘Les Caprichos, ces étincelantes caricatures, en disent plus sur l’Espagne que tous les voyageurs; elles sont bien ce qu’aurait fait Rabelais s’il avait manié le crayon, un Rabelais espagnol bien entendu, sérieux et dont la plaisanterie fait frémir […]. On pourrait ajouter qu’à Paris ils se sont payés 150 et 130 francs, aux ventes Sampayo et Saint-Morys’ (p.385). In the footnote, Brunet mentions some key publications on the Caprichos: Gintrac’s lithography of ‘un des plus charmants caprices de Goya’ in L’Artiste, Gautier’s essays in L’Artiste (1845), the article in Le Revue Encyclopédique [1831, Adélaïde de Montgolfier], and Viardot’s Musées d’Espagne (‘Bulletin bibliographique’, Revue Universelle des Arts, vol.1, pp.384–86). Brunet here is plagiarising Adélaïde de Montgolfier (1831), whose article on Goya he quotes on the footnote but without mentioning her name or indicating that is was a quotation
1865 Étude sur Francisco Goya sa vie et ses travaux : notice biographique et artistique

nodes.label: Yriarte
nodes.works as: inspector of government buildings (by 1856); reporter for Le Monde Illustré during the Spanish campaign in Morocco ('Guerra de África'); editor of Le Monde Illustré in 1862

Goya, sa vie, son œuvre (1867): with 229 artworks. With illustrations by Tabar, Bocourt and Yriarte, including the Maja, The devil's lamp and Saturn (Black Paintings). It mentions, among other works, the Caprichos, the Proverbes (Disparates), and Album A-B (p.93). It mentions Count of Floridablanca, Count of Aranda, and Manuel Godoy (Prince de la Paix)

nodes.id: José de Salamanca y Mayol (I Marqués de Salamanca)
nodes.label: Salamanca
nodes.political views: worked as a politician for the Partido Moderado
in Paris: In 1841: a trip to look for support with the Spanish external debt. He meets with María Cristina de Borbón, who was there in exile, and Narváez (Partido Moderado)
In 1849: he goes into exile for 16 months, until amnesty is given by Narváez
In 1854: he goes into exile for the second time
In 1867: he celebrates his first art sale
nodes.works as: politician, senator, businessman (railway and banking)
nodes.art collection: it included 19 paintings attributed to Velázquez, also to Goya, from the Flemish, Dutch and Italian schools. He has acquired some of these works from the sales of the collections of the Marquis of Leganés and of the Infante Luis de Borbón
nodes.aristocratic titles: I Marquis of Salamanca; I Count of Los Llanos; Grandee of Spain (Grande de España)
nodes.portrayed by: anonymous, drawing; anonymous, photograph
sales: 1867-VI-5 (Paris): more than 200 paintings, artworks and furniture. It included a work by Goya (Femme à l'éventail) (1806-07), and El Greco's La Purificación del Templo, now at the Washington National Gallery of Art
1869 (Sotheby's): pieces acquired by the British Museum; Pieces by José Madrazo
nodes.collector of Goya's works: Femme à l'éventail (1806-07) (1867 sale, lot 177): Musée du Louvre, RF 1132 [https://collections.louvre.fr/ark:/53355/cl010064756]
nodes.curiosities: Salamanca's residence in Madrid, the Palace of the Marquis of Salamanca, now belongs to the BBVA Foundation, where there are two works by Goya: a portrait of Carlos III as a hunter (c.1786), and the portrait of Don Pantaleón Pérez de Nenín (1808). He gives his name to the Neighbourhood of Salamanca (Barrio de Salamanca) in Madrid, where he refurbished 14 blocks

nodes.label: Louise Bertin

nodes.author of: Le Loup-garou (opéra comique) (1827); Fausto (1831); La Esmeralda (1836)

nodes.siblings: Édouard Bertin, Armand Bertin, Geneviève Bertin
nodes.curiosities: she suffered from polio. His father was portrayed by Ingres (1832), and the editor of Le Journal des débats. Berlioz considers her music 'virile, forte et neuve'.

nodes.label: Baudelaire
nodes.author of: Salons (1845, 1846, 1859); Les Fleurs du mal (1857)
writes about Goya: 'Quelques caricaturistes étrangers. Hogarth, Cruikshank, Goya, Pinelli, Brueghel’, Le Présent, vol.2, pp.185–94. This essay also appeared in L’Artiste (26 September 1858, 55–59), in Curiosités Esthétiques (1868) and in OEuvres complètes (1869). Transcribed in Fayos-Pérez 2024, Appendix II, p.344

‘Quelques caricaturistes français’, in Curiosités Esthétiques (1868): ‘Goya, lui aussi, s’est attaqué à la gent monastique. Je présume qu’il n’aimait pas les moines, car il les a faits bien laids; mais qu’ils sont beaux dans leur laideur et triomphants dans leur crasse et leur crapule monacales! [...]' (Fayos Pérez 2024, p.342; Baudelaire – Le Dantec & Pichois 1961, p.997)
nodes.mentions of Goya: letter of 22 Feb 1864 (probably to Charles Yriarte), where he discusses a prospective publication and his previous writings on Goya, and mentions the publications on this artist by Théophile Gautier and Eugène Piot (letter sold in [Autographes des siècles](https://www.autographes-des-siecles.com/produit/charles-baudelaire-revient-a-ses-travaux-sur-francisco-de-goya/))
nodes.curiosities: Baudelaire dedicated his Fleurs du mal (published in 1857) to Gautier ('au poète impeccable'). However, when he was condemned for this work, Gautier remained silent and did not defend him publicly (Les Fleurs du mal, ed. Livre de poche, p.345). Baudelaire was helped, though, by Empress Eugenia de Montijo, to reduce the fee he was sentenced to pay
nodes.bibliography: Fayos Pérez 2024; Chagniot 2016; Baudelaire – Le Dantec & Pichois 1961

nodes.label: Manet
nodes.parents: Eugénie-Désirée Fournier and Auguste Manet
nodes.children: Léon Koelin-Leenhoff
nodes.author of: Le Buveur d'absinthe (1859: rejected at the Salon; Copenhague, Ny Carlsberg Glyptotek); Chanteur espagnol (1860; Salon 1861; Metropolitan); Portrait de M. et Mme Auguste Manet (1860, Orsay); Le Déjeuner su l'herbe (1862); Lola de Valence (painting: 1862; Orsay); Olympia (1863); Le Christ mort et les anges (1864, Metropolitan); L'Homme mort (1864-65, Washington, National Gallery of Art): badly criticized by Théophile Thoré; Combat de taureaux (1865); Le Joueur de fifre (1866); Le Matador saluant (1866-67); L'Exécution de Maximilien (1867); Eva Gonzalès (1869-70, London NG)

Diego Velázquez: 'j'ai, dit-il essayé de faire un type de Paris en mettant dans l'exécution la naïveté du métier que j'ai trouvée chez Vélasquez' (Monneret 1987, p.478)

nodes.label: Thoré
nodes.profession: art critic (from 1832), journalist, art historian, writer, journalist, art collector
nodes.friends: Eugène Delacroix, Ary Scheffer, Alexandre Decamps, Narcisse Virgilio Diaz, David d'Angers, Théodore Rousseau, Paul Lacroix, Paul Mantz
nodes.founder of: the journal La Vraie République (26 March 1848), with collaborators such as George Sand, Pierre Leroux and Armand Barbès; it was banned by Cavaignac (13 June 1848); Journal de la vraie république (9 March 1849)
nodes.sales: 5 December 1892, Hôtel Drouot (L.51162): introduction by Paul Mantz
nodes.partners/lovers: Apolline Lacroix, spouse of Paul Lacroix, curator at the Bibliothèque de l'Arsenal; she would inherit his art collection
